snippet.textDisplay: 2:06 In my country thumbs up is still considered rude by many. I can remember an incidence that made national headlines when a bunch of kids on a schoolbus showed thumbs up to a group of armed personnel in uniform from country's elite force (like US navy seal). They interpreted it as rude although those kids just meant to show their respect and enthusiasm due to the force's recent triumph at an anti-terrorist operation. So the force personnel stopped the bus and tried to press charges. However the misunderstanding was not resolved until after the kids were taken to custody and government intervened. The charges were dropped after such a circus.
snippet.textOriginal: 2:06 In my country thumbs up is still considered rude by many. I can remember an incidence that made national headlines when a bunch of kids on a schoolbus showed thumbs up to a group of armed personnel in uniform from country's elite force (like US navy seal). They interpreted it as rude although those kids just meant to show their respect and enthusiasm due to the force's recent triumph at an anti-terrorist operation. So the force personnel stopped the bus and tried to press charges. However the misunderstanding was not resolved until after the kids were taken to custody and government intervened. The charges were dropped after such a circus.

snippet.textDisplay: The thumb in hand, being shaken is so overused today. Being that it’s a truncated version of the finger pointed out while shaking ones hand, it’s sometimes interpreted as an emasculated version of the finger point while making a fist. The finger point is sometimes interpreted as a phallic thrust. At least according to Desmond Morris.
snippet.textOriginal: The thumb in hand, being shaken is so overused today. Being that it’s a truncated version of the finger pointed out while shaking ones hand, it’s sometimes interpreted as an emasculated version of the finger point while making a fist. The finger point is sometimes interpreted as a phallic thrust. At least according to Desmond Morris.

snippet.textDisplay: Gesturing has also been a bridge between languages.  During work at a theme park, it would help to convey meaning to someone who might have my language, English, as a second or third language skill.  Separately the transition of the "thumbs up" gesture having been rude in some cultures, becoming accepted in current cultures because of globalization, has had an inverse trend with the "OK" sign now becoming toxic--a matter that is difficult to reprogram my lifelong habit, as I would use that even before the thumbs-up gesture.
snippet.textOriginal: Gesturing has also been a bridge between languages.  During work at a theme park, it would help to convey meaning to someone who might have my language, English, as a second or third language skill.  Separately the transition of the "thumbs up" gesture having been rude in some cultures, becoming accepted in current cultures because of globalization, has had an inverse trend with the "OK" sign now becoming toxic--a matter that is difficult to reprogram my lifelong habit, as I would use that even before the thumbs-up gesture.

snippet.textDisplay: What’s really fun is examining gestural use in Sign Language. They often have far more elaborate systems of emblems or “signifiers” to represent ideas. So, instead of having to say that one car hit another car sideways, I can just use the vehicle hand signs, and demonstrate the whole scene. Turn one vehicle handsign into a human handsign, and you can demonstrate a tragedy, or a comedy, as the person blindly faceplants into a parked car.
snippet.textOriginal: What’s really fun is examining gestural use in Sign Language. They often have far more elaborate systems of emblems or “signifiers” to represent ideas. So, instead of having to say that one car hit another car sideways, I can just use the vehicle hand signs, and demonstrate the whole scene. Turn one vehicle handsign into a human handsign, and you can demonstrate a tragedy, or a comedy, as the person blindly faceplants into a parked car.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is one of the reasons that conversations on the internet, through chatrooms and forums and multiplayer games, often have that disconnect. The lack of gestures, as well as the lack of tone, can often lead to misunderstandings and issues. Emojis and the like can help alleviate that a bit, but it's still there.


At the same time, I think this is also why certain people thrive on the internet more than in person. People with social issues, who don't necessarily pick up on those kinds of things in RL, can have an easier time on the internet when those things just aren't present.
snippet.textOriginal:
This is one of the reasons that conversations on the internet, through chatrooms and forums and multiplayer games, often have that disconnect.  The lack of gestures, as well as the lack of tone, can often lead to misunderstandings and issues.  Emojis and the like can help alleviate that a bit, but it's still there.


At the same time, I think this is also why certain people thrive on the internet more than in person.  People with social issues, who don't necessarily pick up on those kinds of things in RL, can have an easier time on the internet when those things just aren't present.

snippet.textDisplay:
Question for the comments: when you use air quotes, how do you move your fingers?
I’ve always moved them on the beat with the phrases syllables but I’ve seen people just move them in once, once per word and sometimes not move the fingers at all. I want to find out which approach is the most common.
snippet.textOriginal:
Question for the comments: when you use air quotes, how do you move your fingers?
I’ve always moved them on the beat with the phrases syllables but I’ve seen people just move them in once, once per word and sometimes not move the fingers at all. I want to find out which approach is the most common.

snippet.textDisplay:
So Tom, would you say this is why our society has taken to emoji so universally/internationally? Going beyond words and sounds to communicate in a locally known language, people seem to how Always communicated visually with movements, signs and jestors.
Stories/movies show people unknown to each other, such as two different Native American groups communicating with a agreed upon sign language.
Egyptian hieroglyphs were used across 1000s of miles and 1000s of years to communicate an idea and info.
Nobody wants to learn to write, it's coming down to pictographs again.
snippet.textOriginal:
So Tom, would you say this is why our society has taken to emoji so universally/internationally? Going beyond words and sounds to communicate in a locally known language, people seem to how Always communicated visually with movements, signs and jestors.
Stories/movies show people unknown to each other, such as two different Native American groups communicating with a agreed upon sign language.
Egyptian hieroglyphs were used across 1000s of miles and 1000s of years to communicate an idea and info.
Nobody wants to learn to write, it's coming down to pictographs again.

snippet.textDisplay: Excellent video; watched it twice.  Yet my comments are both beside the point; sorry.  (1) Is it just me, or is Tom's thumb incredibly long compared to the width of his hand?  My thumb seems to be about 70% as long as my palm is wide.  His is near 100%.  (2) That dot between the ruled lines just above his right shoulder distracted me.  However, I don't want to make it seem like those are IMPORTANT observations, they aren't.  Great video; fascinating subject.
snippet.textOriginal: Excellent video; watched it twice.  Yet my comments are both beside the point; sorry.  (1) Is it just me, or is Tom's thumb incredibly long compared to the width of his hand?
